gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Physical Oceanographic Characteristics of Herring Nursery Habitats in Prince William Sound, 2010-2012, EVOS Herring Program

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The Prince William Sound population of Pacific herring (Clupea pallasi) is considered resource that has not recovered from the effects of the 1989 oil spill. Numerous research and monitoring programs, funded in large part by the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, provide critical information about about herring populations in Prince William Sound.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The webpage for the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, which was formed to oversee restoration of the injured ecosystem through the use of the $900 million civil settlement, a part which funds Research, Monitoring, and Restoration programs in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: This dataset builds upon a prior study funded by the EVOSTC entitled: Physical factors affecting productivity in juvenile Pacific herring nursery habitats 2007-2008. The objectives were to determine the dominant mechanisms of water exchange and circulation within two experimental fjords; one located in a highly productive sub-region (Simpson Bay) but isolated from exchange of GOA deepwater and one located in a less productive sub-region (Whale Bay) influenced by advection from a nearby tidewater glacial fjord, but open to advection of GOA zooplankton including Neocalanus spp. and Euphausiids. The data may be available by contacting the Principal Investigator. Larger work citations: Gay, S.M. III. 2010. Physical Oceanographic Factors Affecting Productivity in Juvenile Pacific Herring Nursery Habitats. Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Restoration Project Final Report (Project 070817). Prince William Sound Science Center, P.O. Box 705, Cordova, AK 99574, Gay, S.M. III. 2013. Physical Oceanographic Characteristics of Nursery Habitats of Juvenile Pacific Herring. Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Restoration Project Final Report (Project 10100132-E). Prince William Sound Science Center, Cordova, Alaska. Gay, S.M. III. (in prep.) Seasonal and annual variation in physical properties of fjords in Prince William Sound, Alaska used as nurseries by juvenile Pacific herring (Clupea Pallasi). To be submitted in winter of 2016 to Fish. Oceanogr.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: These data are part of the Herring Program of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council (EVOSTC), project number 10100132-E, which is a multi-faceted study to determine why herring populations in Prince William Sound (PWS) remain depressed since the early 1990s. Past research of juvenile Pacific herring in PWS has shown that recruitment is highly influenced by conditions within nursery sites affecting survival within the first year. Important among these factors is the pre-winter condition of juvenile (age-0) herring and the effects of water temperatures on their metabolism. Studies of the physical oceanography of nursery fjords during the Sound Ecosystem Assessment (SEA) program indicate that each site has a unique set of hydrographic conditions that are influenced by both local processes and water exchange between the Gulf of Alaska and PWS. These factors vary significantly depending on geographic location, basin morphometry, watershed topography and proximity to sources of glacial water. This dataset includes the following: 1) temperature and salinity data collected by moored and profiled CTDs; and 2) thermistors strung at specific depth intervals on the moorings. The data were collected from 2010 to 2012, and built upon a 2007-2008 study funded by the EVOSTC (entitled Physical Oceanographic Factors Affecting Productivity in Juvenile Pacific Herring Nursery Habitats, EVOS project numbers: 070817, 080817, 090817) by continuing a hydrographic time series within the four principal PWS nursery fjords: Simpson Bay, Eaglek Bay, Whale Bay, and Zaikof Bay. The data are given in ASCII format, which can be read by any type of text viewing software, such as UNIX based Awk or Generic Mapping Tool (GMT), data visualization and spreadsheet software such as Matlab and Excel, and Microsoft programs such as Notepad and Wordpad. The data are in both raw and processed forms, the latter including quality checking, data reduction and averaging (where appropriate). The CTDs include an SB19plus for profiles, and SB16.03s, SB37s and an SB19.03 for moored data. Pre-cruise and post-cruise calibrations were performed on the instruments before and after program completion.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Following the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill, a group of herring research and monitoring projects were designed to improve predictive models of herring stocks in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska through observations and research. From this particular study, data were collected for the following purposes: 1) to continue measurements of physical properties (T/S data) to characterize the habitat conditions over space and time within four juvenile herring nurseries (i.e. small fjords) in PWS; 2) measure currents spatially to determine advective mechanisms driving water exchange, which affects both zooplankton food sources and larval retention within the fjords; and 3) obtain ancillary weather measurements to help explain drivers of wind and buoyancy forced water currents and variations in physical properties over time. Overall, the objectives of this study were to monitor changes in T/S properties over time and document if and when episodic perturbations occurred due to advection of PWS water. Also, these projects provided a physical context for a suite of biological sampling conducted for the four fjords.

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: This material is based upon work funded by multiple entities, including the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views or positions of funding entities. Standard scientific norms for attribution, credit, and potential co-authorship should be followed when using these data including to the Owners, Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council and other sources of funding. Please let the Owner know when these data are used.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Physical Oceanographic Factors Affecting Productivity in Juvenile Pacific Herring Nursery Habitats, 2007 and 2008, EVOS Herring Program

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: EVOS Project Numbers and Years: 2009: 090817, 2008: 080817; 2007: 070817 Past research of juvenile Pacific herring in PWS has shown that recruitment is highly influenced by conditions within nursery sites affecting survival within the first year. Studies of the physical oceanography of nursery fjords has indicated that each site has a unique set of hydrographic conditions that are influenced by both local processes and water exchange between the GOA and PWS. These factors vary significantly depending on geographic location. The proposed study will build upon past research by continuing a hydrographic time series within nursery fjords and collect high resolution data on currents and hydrography to determine the dominant mechanisms of water exchange and circulation within two experimental fjords; one located in a highly productive sub-region (Simpson Bay) and one located in less productive sub-region influenced by tidewater glacial outflow (Whale Bay). Also, this project will provide a physical context for a suite of biological sampling proposed for these sites.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Prince William Sound Herring Program in the Gulf of Alaska Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Affected Area

gmd:individualName.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council (EVOSTC) initiated funding for the integrated research program in Prince William Sound (PWS) in 2009. The PWS Herring Survey program occurred between 2009 and 2013. The Herring Research and Monitoring (HRM) program began in 2012 and is continuing. The Herring Research and Monitoring program is administrated by the EVOSTC under five-year contracts with a total anticipated duration to be twenty-years in length, concluding in 2032. The HRM program is designed to be able to change focus every five years. This changes the types of data collected and the number of projects within the program. The overarching goal of the HRM program is to improve predictive models of herring stocks through observation and research. The monitoring efforts provide surveys of disease prevalence, adult biomass, juvenile abundance index, and condition of young of the year herring. A series of process studies are aimed at improving our understanding of individual components of the herring life cycle. These studies include determining the age at first spawn, identifying population genetic structure, analysis of herring scales for growth patterns, intensive surveys of juvenile populations and conditions, analysis of fatty acids to determine migration distances, improving validation of acoustic measurements, disease related studies, acoustic tagging, development of nonlethal sampling methods, and modeling of herring populations.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Data available in their native environment and ACSII formats for download in the Alaska Ocean Observing System (AOOS) Gulf of Alaska data portal.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: The CTDs were calibrated periodically at the SBE lab in Bellevue, WA. The processing steps also provided a quality assurance in the data. This involved manually inspecting profile data for the CTDs.
The data were quality checked for spurious values.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Surveys occurred in four small fjords within Prince William Sound (PWS), Alaska surveyed. These include Simpson Bay (60o 36.90’ 145o 55.20’), Eaglek Bay (60o 51.237’ 147o 43.157’), Whale Bay (60o 13.961’ 148o 10.189’) and Zaikof Bay (60o 19.408’ 147o 0.215’). Data were collected using a SeaBird Electronics (SBE) 19.03 CTD profiler and moored SB16.03 and SB37 CTDs. The profiler was calibrated approximately biannually by SBE and the moored CTDs were calibrated prior to and after deployments. The profiler also includes a WetLabs ECO FLSTUB fluorometer/turbidimeter, which provided data on phytoplankton biomass and sediment concentrations. The CTD is accurate to 0.01 C o, 0.001 Siemens/m and 0.25% of full-scale pressure range of 50 to 1000 psia. The fluorescence and turbidity have resolutions of 0.01 μg l-1 chl-a and 0.01 NTU respectively. A description of the methods used for the CTD station placements can be found in the following publications: Gay, S.M. III. 2010. Physical Oceanographic Factors Affecting Productivity in Juvenile Pacific Herring Nursery Habitats. Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Restoration Project Final Report (Project 070817). Prince William Sound Science Center, P.O. Box 705, Cordova, AK 99574, Gay, S.M. III. 2013. Physical Oceanographic Characteristics of Nursery Habitats of Juvenile Pacific Herring. Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Restoration Project Final Report (Project 10100132-E). Prince William Sound Science Center, Cordova, Alaska. Gay, S.M. III and S.L.Vaughan (2001) Seasonal hydrography and tidal currents of bays and fjords in Prince William Sound, Alaska. Fish. Oceanogr. 10 (Suppl. 1), 159-193.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The CTD profile data were processed with standard SBE algorithms, which are part of the SBEData Process software package http://www.seabird.com/software. Examples of settings used are given in the (*.psa) modules listed in this data collection. The data are filtered, aligned and binned into either 1db or 1m depth bins output as ascii (*.cnv and *.asc) files, where * represents the cruise and cast numbers. The file creation dates correspond to the processing dates, and the steps used are as follows: 1) DatCnv - converts hexidecimal data into ascii files that include header data (*.cnv files); 2) manually remove surface bins acquired during soak times by deleting data preceding downcasts; 3) Filter - used on edited files to force similar response times for temperature and pressure; 4) AlignCTD - aligns temperature and conductivity to remove spikes in salinity; 5) LoopEdit - checks for pressure reversals and flag spurious values; 6) Derive1 - calculates additional parameters such as depth (m), density (km m-3) and buoyancy frequency: 7) BinAvg - averages output data as either pressure (db) or depth (m) bins; and 8) ASCII_Out - outputs the results into ascii files w/ column headers of variables. Moored CTDs and thermistors are fixed in place and, therefore, require only conversion to engineering units. This applies mainly to the SB16.03s in which *.hex data are converted by DatCnv into *.cnv files (Note that steps 1 and 6 require calibration data for the specific CTDs). Derive was then the used to calculate additional parameters, such as salinity and water density. The thermistor data were output into tabular ascii files using the HoBo Stowaway software. The SB37 (microcats) require a slightly different procedure, in that the calibration data are included in the headers and the data are uploaded from the instruments in ascii format. To use the Derive module, these data must be first converted into a *.cnv format. This is done with SeaTerm, the communication and data acquisition software for SBE CTDs http://www.seabird.com/software. The software converts the date stamps to julian days in the *cnv files, and to use Derive to calculate variables such as salinity and density, a “dummy” *.cnv file must be entered into the module settings. The program actually uses the calibration coefficients listed in the SB37 output file, however.
